executive_summary: The Burger Restaurants industry has performed well over the past five years as per capita disposable income increased, providing consumers will spend more money to eat away from home. Although the industry experienced increased competition from the broader food service market, burger restaurants still represent the market's largest segment, especially among limited-service restaurants. However, economic slowdowns caused by the COVID-19 pandemic somewhat decreased burger demand. Nevertheless, burgers were highly demanded as a takeout food when a large share of the population stayed home. Industry revenue recovered in 2021 as the government eased COVID-19 restrictions. Consequently, industry revenue is anticipated to grow at a CAGR of 4.1% to $170.1 billion over the past five years, including an expected 2.4% growth in 2023 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 Hurt and Benefited Burger Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Since the food service sector was considered essential, burger restaurants remained open throughout the pandemic. However, they could only offer pick-up and delivery services. The convenience and low prices of most burger offerings prevented industry revenue from falling at a much sharper rate. Most large budget chains experienced a spike in delivery orders as customers refrained from traveling to the stores. To mitigate decreases in dine-in sales, several burger companies partnered with Uber Eats to offer free delivery for a short period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Burger Restaurants Shifted Strategies to Meet Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Domestic consumers have become increasingly health-conscious, often dining at places offering specialized menus or healthier products like chicken or salads. To accommodate these changes, burger restaurants have started altering their menus and offering a more comprehensive range of burgers. Many burger restaurants are now more transparent about the nutritional content of their food. This allows customers to make informed choices about what they eat.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Demand for Alternative Burgers Poses a Challenge
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The uncertainty of alternative burgers can cause waste or leave a restaurant undersupplied, introducing a new challenge many restaurant owners have been reluctant to take on. Historically fast food burger patties are shipped and delivered partially cooked and frozen, making them easy to transport and store without substantial fear of the meat spoiling. However, red meat alternatives like chicken and turkey do not freeze and reheat as well as their beef counterparts because of their lower fat contents.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Changes in Consumer Preferences Might Deter New Entrants
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: New restaurants seeking to enter the food service sector have had a growing choice regarding the type and style of restaurant they want to open. As other styles and concepts like health-focused and chicken-based restaurants, have grown much faster than burger restaurants, they have attracted a larger number of new entrants. The increasing demand for alternative burgers has led to an influx of new entrants, including startups and established food companies. This increased competition makes it more difficult for traditional burger restaurants to compete.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising health consciousness is a primary cause
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: During the outlook period, Americans will continue becoming increasingly health-conscious, especially as younger generations, like millennials, enter the workplace and begin having children.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Burger restaurants will revitalize burger image
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Burger restaurants must work on keeping burgers a popular and sought-after menu item despite burgers having been considered a generally unhealthy meal choice. Many burger restaurants, especially full-service and fast-casual, will adopt menu alterations to maintain consumer interest.

It will be a larger challenge for fast food restaurants because they typically produce their burgers in large quantities, not made to order. These restaurants may offer red meat alternatives but may experience more challenges as white meat products typically do not freeze and reheat as well as red meat and white meat has lower fat content.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Changing preferences to slow new location growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The changing customer preference will slow the growth of new locations that existing restaurants plan to open. Instead, many existing restaurants will seek to grow through acquisitions.

The chicken sandwich war between fast food chains is an example of incumbents copying a popular product of a newer player.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The Burger Restaurants industry has a low market share concentration.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 4 players account for less than 5%

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Food and beverage costs and wages paid remain the most significant expenses, and if these are not managed correctly, owners will have constrained profit.
Heavy fluctuations in input costs make it hard for restaurant owners to establish their budgets, price their menus and size their portions appropriately.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Despite changes in technology, the Burger Restaurants industry will be unable to escape its reliance on labor over the next five years.
The most popular food service provided is on-premise food services where consumers order and pay before receiving their food to eat at the establishment.
The second-most popular service is drive-thru services where customers order, pay and receive food without leaving their car.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry relies heavily on consumer tastes and preferences and broader economic trends such as consumer spending and meals eaten away from home.
The diversified price points across service levels help keep revenue volatility more stable as consumers can trade down during economic declines.

FAQs.question: Does your company partner with local merchants to market your products and services?
FAQs.answer: Restaurants that are able to utilize local supply chains are able to use that as a marketing campaign, targeting younger consumers that value whole and natural foods.

FAQs.question: How do review sites, such as Yelp and Google Reviews, impact sales?
FAQs.answer: Yelp! and Google reviews are increasingly relevant for restaurants in the full-service segment of the industry. Many consumers rely on these ratings to differentiate between competing restaurants.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in high-traffic areas to increase visibility?
FAQs.answer: Restaurants that are located in high-traffic areas tend to draw in larger crowds of customers due to their convenience and access to a large consumer base.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage operating expenses to ensure maximum profitability?
FAQs.answer: Burger restaurants must closely monitor their supplies, such as meat and other burger products to ensure that they do not over order and end up with high levels of food waste.

FAQs.question: Does your company leverage mobile booking applications to streamline the ordering process?
FAQs.answer: Burger restaurants with economies of scale have been able to use mobile applications to help streamline orders for consumers, especially during busy meal times. This is typically only useful or practical for larger restaurant chains.

FAQs.question: What point-of-sale systems does your company use to reduce labor costs?
FAQs.answer: Fast-food and other quick-service industry establishments have been utilizing order kiosks to bypass some frontend labor costs.

FAQs.question: Is your company subject to any franchising laws?
FAQs.answer: Some burger restaurants operate through franchise agreements, those locations must comply with federal franchise laws. As franchising becomes increasingly popular among companies, this will become increasingly prevalent in this industry.

FAQs.question: Is your company compliant with the varying labor regulations across states?
FAQs.answer: Restaurants with locations across the US have to make sure that their labor standards fit each state's individual labor law, such as minimum wage.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover rate compare to your major competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Fast-food burger restaurants typically have higher turnover rates than full-service establishments due to the number of consumers each can accommodate in any given hour.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Full-service establishments are able to charge a slight premium on products due to the increased quality and service they provide. Burger restaurants with economies of scale may be able to reduce costs to increase profitability.

FAQs.question: What is your market position? How can you increase your share of the market?
FAQs.answer: Having a clear market position draws in a large customer base, which gives industry operators a competitive advantage.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your revenue comes from franchises? How do you attract potential franchisees?
FAQs.answer: Franchising in the United States can provide necessary support to owners by providing stable revenue streams.

FAQs.question: Are your franchises located in high-traffic areas? Do you have ample parking for customers?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators tend to locate near highly populated and easy access areas to attract more customers.

FAQs.question: How do you deal with a rise in the healthy eating index to keep up with demand? How do you plan to mitigate this threat?
FAQs.answer: The healthy eating index, which measures the degree that the average American adheres to the consumption guidelines set out by the US Department of Agriculture, is forecast to remain steady.

FAQs.question: Do you keep track of the price of red meat? Do you have fixed, long-term supply contracts with meat suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Red meat is one of the main ingredients in a traditional burger and therefore the price of red meat directly impacts cost structure and menu pricing for industry operators.

FAQs.question: In what ways will your business benefit from the expected increase in consumer spending? Are you prepared for an increase in demand?
FAQs.answer: The Burger Restaurants industry is influenced by changes in consumer spending. As economic conditions improve, personal consumption expenditure typically increases as incomes increase and the unemployment rate falls.
